South Park The Fractured But Whole delivers a sharp and witty experience that embraces the series trademark irreverent humour while expanding its world in engaging ways. The game creates a sense of constant surprise through its bold approach to satire and character interactions. Its pacing remains brisk, ensuring the adventure never loses momentum.
The story follows the children of South Park as they form rival superhero factions, leading to a chaotic conflict filled with sharp parody and memorable twists. Every major character contributes something humorous or unexpected to the unfolding narrative. The script captures the tone of the show with impressive accuracy, resulting in consistently entertaining moments.
Gameplay centres on a tactical turn based combat system that balances accessibility with strategic depth. Players can explore South Park freely, uncovering secrets, side quests and character interactions that add depth to the experience. Combat abilities are diverse and encourage experimentation, making battles consistently enjoyable.
The visuals recreate the look of the television series with remarkable precision. Animations are clean and expressive, ensuring that every joke lands exactly as intended. The vibrant environments and detailed character designs bring the town of South Park to life in a charming and authentic manner.
Overall, South Park The Fractured But Whole succeeds as a humorous and engaging adventure that respects its source material while offering refined gameplay and polished presentation. The narrative remains entertaining throughout, supported by clever writing and memorable moments. With its faithful visuals and enjoyable combat, it stands as a strong entry in the genre.
South Park The Fractured But Whole gets an 8/10.

I had a fun time playing South Park - The Fractured But Whole. Just as in Stick of Truth, the South Park style and humour are captured perfectly and it does really feel like playing through an episode of South Park. The customization in the game is amazing with tons of cosmetics and different playstyles available with tons of references to boot. The combat was honestly what really intrigued me. I loved the tile based combat and playing around with the different attacks to find the play style and team members that suited my playstyle. That being said the game was quite easy even on the most difficult settings. No battle took me more than a single attempt. Not even the final bosses and the secret fight against Morgan Freeman. I understand that the DLC is where you can find more difficulty, but I haven‚Äôt played it yet and if playing on the most difficult setting was trivial I can‚Äôt imagine what normal difficulty plays like. For $40 you get a decent ~20 - 25 hour experience, which to me isn‚Äôt too bad. I think it should be said though that I encountered a lot of glitches that did bring down the experience. There were many times where NPC would get stuck in place, though none were mission critical. As well, I encountered a couple crashes, crashing 2 times before the police station selecting my third class. My biggest complaint doesn‚Äôt even have to do with the game itself, but the fact that it requires you to have an Ubisoft account to run its own separate launcher. It‚Äôs stupid, unnecessary, and should be removed. Fuck Ubisoft.

The game is fun to play and funny, but does have quite a few glitches that take away from the experience. I recommend playing if it‚Äôs something you are already interested in. 7/10 for gameplay brought down to 6.5 due to the bugs and needing an Ubisoft account.

Along with that, I feel that this game has a lot more filler content than the Stick of Truth by a long shot. However looking objectively speaking, it is a better game than Stick of Truth as it includes more character dynamics, references, and people as compared to before.
